displayed_text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Because that also would be a possibility, i.e., come off the trial, do some chemotherapy with the K___ oncologist, and then on the back end, when the chemotherapy is over, come back and do a different clinical trial at that point. Patient: Um hum. Okay. Okay. Okay. And, again, that’s one of the reasons why I wanted to come here, uh, uh, from the um perspective of the options. And, uh, and I, I, maybe I shouldn’t say this because your recorder is here, but I do like, not only the professionalism here, but, I, I like the sense of, uh, caring that the personnel here, uh, express. That’s from everybody within the building when you, when you come in. But the other thing is, when I come here to get lab work done, uh, I only get stuck one time. You know? I don’t like to be a big pincushion and you’ve gotten stuck four or five times, and the person still hasn’t hit the vein. Can I try your other arm? And I’m thinking like, come on, now. This, this reminds me of the time when I was in the Marine Corp. The corpsman do the stuff on purpose. You know? Doctor: Okay. Patient: So it is what it is. But I said that to say the quality of care and the compassion I can see here at J___ H___. I’m not saying it’s not there at K___. There’s some good doctors there, good personnel, that have been very helpful to me. Uh, but, uh, I see it all through the building here when I come here. That’s one thing. I could see it. Doctor: So are we all on the same page now? Patient: Yes. Doctor: It sounds like we’re going to keep you on the study for now. In order to do so, we have to stop the medication to allow this anemia to recover. Hopefully, it will. Uh, so as of today, uh, no more Patient: Okay. Doctor: Until you come back and see us on September the fifth. Uh, L___ will be in touch with you after she comes back. Family Member: She’ll be here tomorrow. Doctor: She actually had to leave unexpectedly because her house had some flooding which she had to take care of, which is why she’s not here.

Patient: I get it. Doctor: It’s the cancer that’s doing all bad things. I care. Family Member: Right. Doctor: The cancer doesn’t care so we need to be ahead of it. Patient: I’m with you. Doctor: Because you know it was nasty when we started. Family Member: I know. Doctor: And we had to-. Patient: Well, how can I get rid of it completely, though? Doctor: Well, we’re going to find out to see if it’s waking up. You’ve had everything under the sun thus far. Family Member: Right. Doctor: We will continue to be as aggressive. If there is something new, we’re probably going to take a sample of that. Patient: Um hum.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Which you know on face value suggests that there’s no additional… Patient: No PSA is not the best marker. Doctor: Exactly. Well it is a great marker but sometimes if the cancer cells that are there are in microscopic clusters… Patient: Sure. Doctor: …and they’re not organized enough… Patient: Right. Doctor: …to produce… Patient: Okay. Doctor: …or get their machinery organizes, organized or orchestrated, there’s music… Doctor: …enough to produce enough PSA that we can detect in our blood tests… Patient: Sure. Doctor: …then you know it may take a little while for that to show up.

Patient: Is that just starting? Doctor: Uh, that has been open probably for a couple of months. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But it has a lot of rules. Either, you have to be AR-V7 positive. So, we would have to draw a tube of blood. Uh, and that we can do. Uh, it takes a week to come back. If you scream positive with that as positive, then the team could talk to you about the study. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. If you’re negative, then you’re not eligible from the get-go. Patient: Right. Doctor: Because you have to be positive to go onto that study. The other two studies, it doesn’t matter about what your AR-V7. AR-V7 gives us a sense of what’s the likelihood that Enzalutamide’s gonna work. Patient: Okay. Doctor: What’s the likelihood that Abiraterone’s gonna work. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Um. In this case, we’re trying to just sort out men who, um, have an AR-V7 positive as a bad thing. Uh. So, that says that we’re willing to go with immune therapy which hasn’t been proven at a high risk/high gain, uh, thing in that kind of individual.

Family Member: Sure. Uh is there any data on uh chemotherapy? Doctor: Yeah, yeah. Chemotherapy is standard and approved. Family Member: Right. Doctor: So the chances of that helping the – the other part is a lot of these new treatments like the Xofigo for instance, the radiation, it doesn’t make the PSA go down. So its the PSA effect is frequently treatment dependent. Okay so chemotherapy or XTANDI for that matter we know it makes the PSA go down if it’s working. Family Member: Mm Hmm. Doctor: But not so for Xofigo and for this new medication honestly we don’t know enough- Patient: Yeah. Doctor: -to say that there is absolutely has the same effect as chemotherapy on PSA or it has the effect like Xofigo. So that’s something we’ll find out but I think if everything else is lining up that you’re doing well on this treatment. I don’t think we should just make a decision and jump off the treatment is the PSA is going up. Patient: Oh. Family Member: That makes sense. And what if his bone scan is positive? The one he just had. Is the… Doctor: Yeah so if it shows progression, then I think we have to look – change gears to a different treatment and that’s where all those options come in whether to do chemotherapy, whether to do Xofigo or whether to do that new hormonal pill. So any of those are equally good options. Family Member: Okay. Patient: I see.

Family Member: Right? Am I wrong there? Doctor: Well, it isn’t. You know what it is? It creates an unhealthy environment for you. And for all the other stuff I may potentially have to do for you, to you, however we want to say that, I need you functioning and that diabetes can’t be in my way. Gosh darn it. Doctor: Yeah. Plus unregulated, and I mean this up and down, your body just doesn’t like it. So the steady state might be alright at a hemoglobin A one C of seven two but your every day, what you get is tired. You crash. You go back up. You’re good. You crash. You’re tired. You come back up. That’s not, boom, okay. Patient: So then like I again explained to Dr. W___ about my, about my fatigue. Doctor: Um hum. Yes. Patient: Is my lack of uninterrupted sleep. I just don’t get it. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: I don’t get – there’s never a night that I get three or four hours uninterrupted sleep. Doctor: Cause you’re peeing? Patient: Um, yes. Doctor: Yeah. So what time do you stop drinking? Patient: Every time I get up, I drink some more water. (Laughter)

Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So that is why we give both drugs in combination. And what happens is on a monthly basis through about twenty-eight day treatment cycles the testosterone goes from being super-high, much higher than your body would be able to make on its own back down to super-low. PAT Uh huh. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So every twenty-eight days which is roughly every four weeks, your testosterone will spike for a few days and then within about a week it will drop down to the very low levels. Patient: When you say spike, what numbers have you seen? Doctor: Right, so I told you before that a real low testosterone level for someone your age might be let’s say a hundred fifty to two hundred milligrams per deciliter. Here, they’re talking about between one thousand and one thousand five hundred milligrams per deciliter. So it’s a five- to ten-fold increase above the physiological level. So we call this super-physiological. That means higher than physiological. Patient: Right, okay. Doctor: So again, since you’re not eligible for that at this point in time - Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: A minimum PSA for that trial has to be above one. Patient: Okay. Doctor: One point zero. But just to prepare for the future –

Family Member 1: Yeah, I don’t have any additional questions. Doctor: Great. Patient: There you go. Thank you. Family Member: I have a very basic question. Doctor: Of course. Family Member: What does cure mean? Doctor: Cure means that once we’re done all this therapy, the cancer is gone forever. Family Member: So, so yeah - Doctor: Which we won’t know for five, ten years. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Unfortunately you know you’re a survivor now. Patient: Right.

Patient: Right. Doctor: But because of that threat I’m tempted to say maybe we should get it in control while we can rather than waiting until that bad outcome happens. Okay? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So that’s why I’ll have Dr. C____ come in first, explain the procedure, what it involves, what the risks are, all of that – Patient: Yeah. Doctor: - and then I’ll just touch base with you after he’s spoken to. Okay? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So that way if any questions… Family Member: You’ll come back today you mean? Doctor: Yeah. I do. Yeah, yeah. Family Member: I didn’t know if we have to come back. Doctor: I figured if he explained to you first and then if any questions come up and all that, I will come back. Family Member: Okay.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And your PSA will also be lower. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Because part of the PSA going up with the testosterone was just turning on the production number. Patient: Of the testosterone? Doctor: Even if it didn’t make the cancer grow, or, or the cancer grew, whatever, just turning off the, the hormone might turn off the production. So, um, usually I see the PSA drop back down some. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So lots of things to throw at you. So what I’m going- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: My work is going to be to figure out what it would cost us to get on the Xtandi. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And then this biopsy part of the trials, what, what’s required. Patient: Okay.

Patient: And then it feels so funny man like… Doctor: Okay, I got it. Let me have gastroenterology see you because they may need to scope you both down below as well as in the stomach, okay? First of all because your diarrhea is not something that’s typically happens with this chemotherapy. Okay so we need to get to the bottom of what’s causing you diarrhea also. Alright? Patient: Right. That’s the - that’s the thing that they, man, I can eat, I can eat, but. Doctor: Okay. I got that. Patient: I couldn’t eat nothing. Doctor: But you could not… Patient: I could eat nothing for about, about at least about two days. Doctor: Okay so let me send me over to chemo. Okay? We’ll do the chemo today, but meanwhile I’m going to call our radiologist and see if they can tell me something about the CAT scan. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Then I’ll come over there and talk to you about it. Patient: Let me ask you something, let me ask you something Dr. B____. What is what is better, CAT scan or ah MRI? Doctor: It depends on what part of the body we’re looking at. But a CAT scan is pretty good, it’s a pretty good test. If we don’t find something or need to look at it more. Patient: You said it’s not showing on the…

Patient: Okay. Doctor: I mean really undetectable and we have to because a part of yours went into the seminal vesicle- Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: -we had to be very careful about following up on it because there’s a slight risk that it may reoccur, so we’ll follow it and follow it very carefully. Patient: I’ve been trying eat right, I’ve been trying to eat stuff, you know I’ve been trying to do my own you know like doing research and stuff that’s good for me. Doctor: Good. That’s good. Patient: Berries and <____>. Doctor: High fiber, low fat? Patient: Yes. As much as I can. Doctor: And you’re in good shape where you don’t have a big belly or anything like that. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: So that’s good.

Patient: And I just wondered you know with. Doctor: Yes. Yeah I agree with you. Patient: As far as, as far as… Doctor: It’s not a trivial issue by any means. Patient: But you know like I say with the PSA if it’s up and everything but the scans the CT scans are good I mean if they’re… Doctor: Yeah, so that’s a good situation to be in is what I’ll tell you. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You know then clearly me telling you you know what things are getting worse just come off this and go get… Patient: Yeah, that’s right. Doctor: Because that would be a really bad outcome overall. Patient: Yeah but it’s not like that so that’s… Doctor: Yeah, that’s a good thing. That’s why we’re having this back and forth even. Patient: Yes.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.2 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::2 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.disagree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::disagree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.strongly disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups::: strongly disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.strongly disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers::: strongly disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Black or African American: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Black or African American

displayed_text: Patient: So we know still it’s invisible somewhere, so we can target what we can see. And we can still deal with you know what we can’t see. If that’s the combination of your thinking in terms of correct or that is a possibility? Doctor: I’m thinking that in terms of the sequence if you get the radiotherapy first. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: That does not close the door to getting hormone therapy down the line. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: You start with the hormone therapy, the other option is going to disappear very quickly. And a radiation oncologist is not going to know what to target. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: It would be very different if the spot was in the bone. Bone metastasis takes a very long time to disappear. Sometimes you know a small one can take up to a year to disappear. So oftentimes when a cancer is involved, when they start the hormone therapy about three months later, a week later, two weeks later you talk to the radiation oncologist and by the time he starts the radiation planning which might be six to eight weeks later, the spot is still where he can see it, he can zap it and target that. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: And with a lymph node, uh if we start the hormone therapy even like a couple of weeks before that thing’s going to disappear; he won’t know what he’s targeting. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So all I’m saying is in theory that-

Patient: Then you’re gonna schedule me up to get the yoo-yoo. Doctor: The yoo-yoo’s the biopsy. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: He knows he has to have it. He knows he just had a scan. M_’s gonna go as quick as she can to get things rollin’. So. Healthcare Professional 2: Well, can you come Tuesday? (Laughs) Patient: Next Tuesday? Healthcare Professional 2: ‘Cuz we had a cancellation. Doctor: Okay! If it’s for Mr. L_, it’s fine. Patient: Next, next Tuesday? What day is, what day, what date is that? Healthcare Professional 2: What date? Doctor: Ummmm. Healthcare Professional 2: Ummmmm.
